data.title: Using Computer Vision to Win at Duck Hunt
data.description: Abhinav Mandava leverages object detection models and Roboflow to create an aimbot (which automates aiming and firing for the player) for Duck Hunt.

data.title: Using Unity Perception to train an object detection model with synthetically generated images
data.description: Collecting images and annotating them with high-quality labels can be an expensive and time-consuming process. The promise of generating synthetic data to reduce the burden is alluring. In the past we have covered techniques such as augmentation, context synthesis, and model assisted labeling to improve the process. In this post,

data.title: Computer Vision Use Cases in Healthcare and Medicine
data.description: Computer vision technology continues to expand its use cases in healthcare and medicine. In this post, we will touch on some exciting example use cases for vision in healthcare and medicine and provide some resources on getting started applying vision to these problems.

data.title: Announcing Model Assisted Labeling
data.description: Now you can use trained models to speed up your annotation flow.One of the most time-consuming parts of the computer vision workflow is curating a high-quality dataset. When we launched Roboflow Annotate last month we aimed to streamline this process by launching an easy to use image annotation tool

data.title: Using Computer Vision to Detect Package Deliveries
data.description: My concern is getting to packages before my dog opens one. There are monthly subscriptions, but with Roboflow and a couple of tools, I can do this locally.

data.title: Teams for All: Create Free Teams on Roboflow
data.description: Machine learning is a team sport, and getting a computer vision model to production is no exception. All parts of the process are improved with a team: collecting data from multiple sources; annotating data with colleagues; sharing versioned datasets; and using deployed models. We're pleased to introduce free teams on

data.title: A Primer on Transfer Learning
data.description: Transfer learning is using what a given model has learned about one domain and applying those learnings to attempt to learn a related problem.

data.title: Announcing Roboflow’s Seed Round
data.description: Computer vision is a generational technology. Like the PC, internet, and mobile phones, computer vision’s impact will reshape every industry. data.title: How to Try CLIP: OpenAI's Zero-Shot Image Classifier
data.description: Earlier this week, OpenAI dropped a bomb on the computer vision world.

data.title: Using the Upload API to Collect Images from the Wild
data.description: The key to production quality machine learning models is continuous iteration and improvement. The first step is getting a model that is "good enough" for your first version. But once you deploy to the real world you'll invariably find edge cases that confuse your model. Collecting data from the field

data.title: Using Public Datasets to Improve your Computer Vision Models
data.description: Ok, so you've trained a model and it's not doing as well as you'd hoped. Now what? You could experiment with augmentation, try a different architecture, or check your training data for errors. But what if those all fail? Oftentimes, the single most impactful thing you can do to improve

data.title: Introducing the Object Count Histogram
data.description: We are excited to announce the introduction of object count histograms, now available in the Roboflow dataset health check.

data.title: Using Computer Vision to Boost Cities' Efficiency by Reallocating Police Resources
data.description: Data scientist Joseph Rosenblum leverages his past law enforcement experience and details how to make cities more efficient while minimizing bias.

data.title: Roboflow Changelog: January 2021
data.description: Welcome to our monthly changelog where we catalog our recent feature additions and improvements. If you missed it, you can find last month's changelog here. data.title: Football, Kaggle, Roboflow: Using Computer Vision to Tackle Helmet Safety
data.description: If you're searching for a dataset to use or are looking to improve your data science modeling skills, Kaggle is a great resource for free data and for competitions. For example, there's currently an open Kaggle competition detecting American football helmet impacts (crashes) in which you can compete through early

data.title: Get a Hosted API for your Object Detection Model
data.description: Roboflow provides tools for labeling, organizing, and training a computer vision model. Once you finish running one of the Jupyter notebooks from our Computer Vision tutorials you can download a weights file optimized for making predictions on your custom dataset. data.title: How To Annotate Images with Your Team Using Roboflow
data.description: Dataset annotation is better with teams: you can move more quickly, keep everyone on the same page, track annotation progress, and easier provide examples of what the ultimate dataset should look like. In this post, we'll walkthrough an example workflow of annotating data with your team using Roboflow Pro.  The

data.title: Tackling the Internet of Things with Roboflow: Object Detection Apps on Android
data.description: Joo chan Kim, PhD student, is developing an object detection application for Android devices that can identify specific IoT sensors by using a custom detection model.

data.title: How to Train Scaled-YOLOv4 to Detect Custom Objects
data.description: Object detection technology advances with the release of Scaled-YOLOv4. This blog is written to help you apply Scaled-YOLOv4 to your custom object detection task, to detect any object in the world, given the right training data.

data.title: Apple's M1 is up to 3.6x as fast at training machine learning models
data.description: We compared the Apple M1 chip to the Intel Core i5 chip on an object detection task using Create ML.

data.title: Unveiling Our New Limited Edition T-Shirt
data.description: A huge benefit of working for Roboflow is interacting with all the builders and creators using our platform. Every day, Roboflow users are experimenting with computer vision to solve fascinating problems and we're always impressed with their creativity. data.title: Introducing Roboflow Annotate
data.description: Since we launched Roboflow in early 2020, our vision has always been to improve and streamline the workflow of computer vision projects so that developers can focus on the parts of their project that are unique, not on reinventing the wheel. data.title: Share Your Datasets with the Computer Vision Community
data.description: Roboflow users share their datasets with the public to improve computer vision research and contribute to the broader computer vision community.

data.description: Opening a notebook and your kernel instantly dies, or you haven't been able to get a notebook running on M1 yet. That's why we're here!

data.title: Generating Renaissance Art with Computer Vision
data.description: Data scientists Samay Lakhani and Sujay Sundar use Roboflow and computer vision to generate Renaissance-style abstractions.

data.title: Seven Tips for Labeling Images for Computer Vision
data.description: This guide walks through tactics to ensure your dataset is as high quality as possible for computer vision tasks.

data.title: What is Computer Vision? An Introduction for Beginners
data.description: After reading this post, you should have a good understanding of computer vision without a strong technical background and you should know the steps needed to solve a computer vision problem.
